results.title: China today. No. 8102
results.creator_credit: Film Studio of the Peoples Republic of China
results.brief_description: Shows various views of China: new housing in Beijing’ cloud design brocades; the desire of an overseas Chinese; the famous “Bai Feng Wan” pills; extracts from the dance drama “Flying to the moon”.

results.title: China today. No. 8101
results.creator_credit: Central Newsreel and Documentary Film Studio of the People's Republic of China
results.brief_description: Chinese cinemagazine items: 1. Uses of remote sensing - Talks about China’s use of remote sensing to detect targets on the forest floor. 2. Reform school - Shows footage of a reform school full of juvenile delinquents whose crimes were not bad enough for jail. 3. Ancient ape fossil - Archeologists show us ape fossils from hundreds of years ago, which show the transition from ape to humans. 4. Stereotaxic brain apparatus - Shows the equipment helping neuro surgeons in treating patients with Parkinson Disease. 5. Wool-knitting - Shows the many patterns and items of clothing a pair of knitting needles can produce. 6. Quanqzhou Foreign Trade Center - Shows footage of the Center’s show-room for China’s export commodities.

results.title: China today. No. 804
results.creator_credit: Film Studio of the Peoples Republic of China
results.brief_description: Birthday banquet for old friend Dutch filmmaker John Ibens celebrates his 81st birthday through the Chinese Ministry Culture. “Ping Pong at the seashore” A training seminar for up coming ping-pong championships. “New job opportunities for urban youth” 1200 workers have been employed at the news sheet factory in Shanghai. “New method for processing metals” A new way of processing metals through controlled explosion. “Lashau Botanical Garden” A garden laboratory that looks at the study of new plant life and the domestication of wild plants. More than 3400 plants are cultivated at the Lashau garden.

results.title: China Rising
results.creator_credit: Gwyneth Hughes, Yorkshire Television and Granite Productions
results.brief_description: A series of three two part programs that detail the history of China during a number of tumultuous stages in its history. The first program explores the period in Chinese history between the 1920s through to the 1940s, seen through the eyes of the people living in Shanghai, as the country moved from the colonial rule of the English and Japanese and the disjointed rule of the warlords to a unification movement led by the Nationalists under Chiang Kai-Shek and subsequent attempts by the Japanese to regain control. The second two part program covers the history of Communist China from the mid 1930s to the 1960s, where the chinese Communists retreated following defeat by the Nationalists in the walk later known as the Long March, only to regroup and counter attack in the form of the Peoples Liberation Army to drive the Nationalists out of power and to exile in Taiwan. Part three of the series covers the period of Mao’s Cultural Revolution and the subsequent changes which inspired the student democracy movement of the late 1980’s through discussion of the revolution’s impact on families and the classes and the economic reforms of the 1980s following the revolutions decline. This comphrehensive documentary uses rare archival footage and interviews with the chinese people of the time and engages with the impact this constantly revolutionary period of Chinese history had on their lives. Each program in the series includes Teachers notes.

results.title: China mission
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Michael Scott, Lydia Semotuk and Tom Radford
results.brief_description: A biography of Chester Ronning told through the use of mostly contemporary stills and some silent footage. Chester Ronning was born in Francheng, China, in 1894, the son of Norwegian missionaries. Until his death at the age of ninety, he was everything from a cowboy to an ambassador, a college president to a Peace River homesteader, a missionary to a member of the Alberta legislature. But Ronning, who died in December 1984, is best remebered in international circles for his long and close relationship with China. Throughout his many careers, including that of Canadian High Commissioner to India, ambassador to Norway, and head of an international mission in 1966 to end the war in Vietnam, Ronning’s lifelong ambition was to explain China to the western world. His story is a rare example of the meeting of east and west in a compassionate, remarkable man. Narrated by Cedric Smith. (Awards: San Antonio; San Francisco).
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Michael Scott, Lydia Semotuk and Tom Radford

results.title: China dolls
results.creator_credit: Helen Bowden, Film Australia and Tony Ayres
results.brief_description: In this documentary about the experience of being gay and Asian in Australia, filmmaker Tony Ayres blends his own story about coming to terms with his race and sexuality with that of men he interviews. Born in Hong Kong, Ayres grew up in Australia denying his Chinese identity. Ironically, it was only when he realised he was gay that the full implications of his ethnicity became apparent. Focusing on the contradictions of being part of a ‘double minority’, Ayres exposes the ways that the ideals of beauty and youth promoted in contemporary gay culture are saturated with racial stereotypes. Where the dominant iconography of sexual desirability and masculinity is almost exclusively Caucasian, gay Asian men are either rendered invisible or portrayed as soft and ‘feminine’. Ayres own story of coming to terms with the complexities of his identity and the stories of the subjects of his film (who include photographer and performance artist William Yang and actor Anthony Wong) reveal how gay Asian Australian men are overturning old stereotypes and forging new identities for themselves.
